page.title: 14KENTISH RAGSTONE
page.content: It is impossible to walk around Boughton Monchelsea and Loose without noticing the buildings and walls of Kentish ragstone. This hard grey limestone is drawn from the geological formation known as the Hythe Beds of the Lower Greensand, and for centuries it has been quarried for use both locally and further afield. The Roman walled cemetery at Boughton used it. In Norman times it was employed in the building of London's White Tower and Westminster Abbey; a royal command decreed that "no Kentish Ragstone shall be carted to London for any other purpose until the Abbey is built". Rochester Castle was repaired with it and in 1419 Henry V ordered 7000 stone cannon-balls from the quarries here. Many of Maidstone's public buildings are of ragstone, but none is quarried now in this area.
